page.title: International League of Iberian and Latin American Women

revision.text:
'''International League of Iberian and Latin American Women''' ('''Liga Internacional de Mujeres Ibéricas e Hispanoamericanas''') is an international organization of Latin American and Iberian women. It was formed in 1921 by liberal feminists from both regions. Early on the league was led by [[Paulina Luisi]] of Uruguay, while [[Carmen de Burgos]] of [[Madrid]] served as its first president, and [[Elena Arizmendi Mejia]] was the founding vice president. During the 1920s, national chapters emerged.<ref name="Smith2008">{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Bonnie G.|title=The Oxford Encyclopedia of Women in World History: 4 Volume Set|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EFI7tr9XK6EC&pg=PA601|year=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-514890-9|pages=601–}}</ref> The league served as a national alternative to the US-dominated [[Inter-American Commission of Women]] (IACW) of the [[Pan-American Union]] into the 1930s.<ref name="Thayer2009">{{cite book|last=Thayer|first=Millie|title=Movement Or Market?: Rural Women, NGO Activists, and Northern Donors in Brazil|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=88SLAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA229|date=16 October 2009|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-19777-3|pages=229–}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{women-hist-stub}} [[Category:Organizations established in 1921]] [[Category:Feminist organizations]]

{{Infobox artist | name = Jovita Idár | image = Jovita Idár.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1885|9|7|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Laredo, Texas]],
[[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1946|6|15|1885|9|7|mf=y}} | death_place = [[San Antonio, Texas]],
[[United States]] | nationality = American | field = [[Journalism]],
[[Teaching]] | training = | movement = [[Orden Caballeros de Honor;The First Mexican Congress]],
[[La Liga Femenil (League of Mexican Women)]] | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = }} '''Jovita Idár''' (September 7, 1885, – June 15, 1946) was an American journalist, political activist and civil rights worker, who fought for the rights of Mexican Americans and women. She worked as a teacher but turned to journalism and worked at her father's newspaper, ''La Crónica''.“Texas Originals.” Jovita Idár | Humanities Texas, [http://www.humanitiestexas.org/programs/tx-originals/list/jovita-idar www.humanitiestexas.org/programs/tx-originals/list/jovita-idar]. Retrieved 02 April 2018. == Early Years == Jovita Idár was born in [[Laredo, Texas]] in 1885.Handbook of Texas Online - Idar, Jovita. http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fid03. Retrieved on 2009-07-23. She was one of eight children of Jovita and Nicasio Idár {{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Nancy Baker|title=IDAR JOVITA|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fid03|website=TSHA|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=2018-04-04}} who strove to advance the civil rights of Mexican-Americans. All eight Idar children grew up in an atmosphere where rights, responsibilities and the circumstances of the Chicano community were consistently discussed. In the book ''Marching to a Different Drummer,'' Robin Kadison Berson explains “Growing up Jovita was an imaginative, spirited girl; eager student, she won prizes for her poetry and enjoyed reciting before an audience.”Berson, Robin Kadison.Marching to a Different Drummer: Unrecognized Heroes of American History.Greenwood Publishing Group,1994. Idár and two of her brothers, Eduardo and Bobby Brown, worked for the newspaper ''La Crónica'' [The Chronicles]. The paper, edited and published by their father Nicasio Idár, advocated for civil rights and social justice for [[Mexican-American]]s. A strong, proud man, Nicasio turned the newspaper into a major voice for justice and [[Tejano]] rights. Jovita wrote articles under a pseudonym, exposing the poor living conditions of Mexican-American workers and supported the [[Mexican Revolution]] which began in 1910.Pouwels, Joel Bollinger. ''Political Journalism by Mexican Women During the Age of Revolution 1876-1940''. Edwin Mellon Press, 2006, p. 58.Gutierrez-Witt, Laura. "Cultural Continuity in the Face of Change: Hispanic Printers in Texas". In ''Recovering the U.S. Hispanic Literary Heritage'', Vol. II. (Eds. [[Erlinda Gonzales-Berry]] and Chuck Tatum). Arte Publico Press, 1996. According to Laura Gutierrez in volume two of ''Recovering the U.S. Hispanic Literary Heritage'', the newspaper ''La Crónica'':Gutierrez-Witt 1996. {{Quote|... including a wide variety of articles dealing with current events, news from Mexico, local and regional news, biographical and historical essays, poetry, literary essays, commentary, and, of course, lots of advertisements. More importantly, however, La Cronica gave voice to the serious social and economic disparities suffered by Mexicans in Texas and the U.S.}} == Career == Idár earned her teaching certificate in 1903 from the [[Holding Institute]] in Laredo.Pouwels, ''Political Journalism by Mexican Women''. She taught in a school in [[Los Ojuelos]], located approximately 40 miles east of Laredo.Handbook of Texas - Idar, Joavita The reality of her first years teaching was frustrating, “There was never enough textbooks for her pupils, nor enough paper, pens or pencils; if all her students came to class, there were not enough chairs or desk for them.”.Berson, Robin Kadison.Marching to a Different Drummer: Unrecognized Heroes of American History.Greenwood Publishing Group,1994. The schooling for Chicano students, much like African American students in the south at that time, was inadequate. Chicanos paid taxes to support decent schooling for their children yet, they were denied from entering. By this time Idar realized that her teaching efforts were making little impact on student lives due to the ill-equipped segregated schools. She decided that journalism offered more of a meaningful change that would be effective and she returned to Laredo to write for ''La Cronica''. In 1910 La Cronica criticized the different social relations between the Hispanic communities and the Anglo people, “Featuring stories on educational and social discrimination against Mexican Americans, poor economic conditions, decreasing use of the Spanish language, the loss of Mexican culture and lynching of Hispanics.”JONES, NANCY BAKER."IDAR, JOVITA."JONES, NANCY BAKER. June 14, 2010.Accessed February 12, 2018. https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fid03. By 1911 La Cronica had shifted towards supporting revolutionary forces, “the newspaper called a convention of the Orden Caballeros de Honor, a fraternal order to discuss the troubling social issues at the time” == Movements == '''La Liga Femenil (League of Mexican Women)''' Idár served as the first president of the League of Mexican Women (La Liga Femenil Mexicanista). It was founded in October 1911 in Laredo to offer free education to Mexican children.Villegas de Magnón, Leonor. ''The Rebel''. Arte Publico Press, 1994. Additional goals of the organization were to "unify the Mexican intellectuals of Texas around the issues of protection of civil rights, bilingual education, the lynching of Mexicans, labor organizing and women's concerns."Lomas, Clara. "Historical Newspapers". In ''The Oxford Encyclopedia of Latinos and Latinas in the United States''. (Eds. Suzanne Oboler and Deena J. González). Oxford University Press, 2005. The women within this league worked to transform these injustices into a plan of action and focused on relieving social problems through actively making changes within their communities. Women who participated in this organization were highly influential. “Some league members were trained educators and professionals, and the education of youth remained the organization's primary focus.”Ramos, Raĺul A., and Monica Perales. Recovering the U.S Hispanic Literary Heritage Series: Recovering the Hispanic History of Texas. Arte Publico Press, 2010. It developed into a social, political and charitable organization for women that, in part, provided food and clothes to those in need.Handbook of Texas Online - Liga Femenil Mexicanista. http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/vql01. Retrieved on 2009-07-23. '''Primer Congreso Mexicanista''' Idar also participated in the Primer Congreso Mexicanista,Meier, Matt S. and Margo Gutierrez. ''Encyclopedia of the Mexican American Civil Rights Movement''. Greenwood Press, 2000, p. 113. an organization dedicated to fighting inequality and racism.Pardo, Mary S. "Latina Labor and Community Organizers". In The Oxford Encyclopedia of Latinos and Latinas in the United States." (Eds. Suzanne Oboler and Deena J. González). Oxford University Press, 2005. These associations actively worked for the advancement of their members, “by holding studying and learning sessions, sessions where culture is acquired and talent is developed without orgies and unhealthy ambitions.”Turner, Elizabeth Hayes, Stephanie Cole, and Rebecca Sharpless. Texas women: their histories, their lives. Athens, GA: The University of Georgia Press, 2015. Idar promoted the values of the "gente decente," self-identified decent, honest and respectable people, as the solution to the social problems faced by marginalized communities, “Idar promoted the idea that education elevated women and by extension men” she reflected an ideal of feminism that was not completely against Victorian concepts, but she did challenge ideas and broke boundaries of the patriarchal society of her time. In 1913 during the [[Mexican Revolution]] Idár and a friend entered Mexico to help care for the wounded along the border region. She later joined a medical group called the White Cross ([[La Cruz Blanca]]) which was similar to the Red Cross relief organization.Handbook of Texas - Idar, Jovita. After returning to Laredo Idár worked for the newspaper ''El Progreso'' where she protested against the dispatch of U.S troops to border through a written editorial. This offended the U.S Army and [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Rangers]], causing the rangers to force the shutdown of ''El Progreso''.{{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Nancy Baker|title=IDAR, JOVITA|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fid03|website=TSHA|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=2018-04-04}} After her father's death in 1914, she eventually returned to operate ''La Crónica'',{{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Nancy Baker|title=Jovita Idar|url=https://www.womenintexashistory.org/audio/idar/|website=Women in Texas History|publisher=Venue Communications, Inc|accessdate=2018-04-04}} where she continued to expose the conditions that Mexican-Americans and Mexican immigrants were living under at the time. She also founded the weekly paper ''Evolución'' in November 1916 which lasted four years.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} == Marriage and Later Years == In May 1917 Idár married Bartolo Juárez, who worked as a plumber and tinsmith.''Laredo Times''. May 27, 1917, page 7. She moved with her husband to [[San Antonio]] in 1921. There she founded a free kindergarten and also volunteered in a hospital as an interpreter.{{cite web|title=Great Texas Women|url=https://texaswomen.housing.utexas.edu/pdfs/GTWContent.pdf|publisher=UTSA 's Institute of Texas Cultures|accessdate=2018-04-04}} In 1940 she co-edited the journal ''El Heraldo Cristiano''.Villegas de Magnón. ''The Rebel''. She remained in this city until her death on June 15, 1946.[http://www.humanitiestexas.org/programs/tx-originals/list/jovita-idar] Article in ''Humanities Texas: Texas Originals'' Her death was said to be caused by a [[pulmonary hemorrhage]] and that she had been suffering from advanced [[tuberculosis]].{{cite news|last1=Danini|first1=Carmina|title=1900s journalist and educator Jovita Idar championed rights of Mexican Americans|url=https://www.expressnews.com/sa300/article/1900s-journalist-and-educator-Jovita-Idar-12454358.php|accessdate=2018-04-04|agency=Express-News|publisher=San Antonio Express News}} == References == {{reflist|}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|chapter=Jovita Idar: The Ideological Origins of a Transnational Advocate for ''La Raza''|last=González|first=Gabriela|title=Texas Women: Their Histories, Their Lives|year=2015|location=Athens, GA|publisher=University of Georgia Press|pages=225{{endash}}248|editor1=Turner, Elizabeth Hayes|editor2=Cole, Stephanie|editor3=Sharpless, Rebecca}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Idar, Jovita}} [[Category:1885 births]] [[Category:1946 deaths]] [[Category:American women journalists]] [[Category:Civil rights activists]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American women journalists]] [[Category:American people of Mexican descent]]

{{Infobox person | name = Kantano Habimana | image = Kantano Habimana.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = allegedly before 2002<ref name= "hirondelle 01">{{cite news |title=CONVICTED ITALO-BELGIAN "HATE-RADIO" PRESENTER BEGINS TESTIMONY |author=FH |url=http://www.hirondellenews.org/ictr-rwanda/377-trials-ended/media-trial/18871-en-en-convicted-italo-belgian-qhate-radioq-presenter-begins-testimony79227922 |newspaper=Hirondelle News Agency |date=27 February 2002 |accessdate=22 March 2013}}</ref> | death_place = | occupation = Radio presenter (''animateur''), journalist | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''Kantano Habimana''', commonly referred to as '''''Kantano''''', was a presenter (''animateur'') on the Rwandan radio station [[Radio Télévision Libre des Mille Collines]] (RTLM), which played a significant role in promoting the [[Rwandan Genocide]]. Like the station's [[RTLM#Individuals_associated_with_the_station|other broadcasters]], Habimana incited violence against [[Tutsi]] and moderate [[Hutu]] on the air.<ref>The Prosecutor v. Ferdinand Nahimana, Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, Hassan Ngeze (Judgement and Sentence), ICTR-99-52-T, International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR), 3 December 2003, available at: http://www.refworld.org/docid/404468bc2.html [accessed 21 December 2017]</ref>
Habimana is often named as both the most popular<ref>{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=Allan (Ed.) |authorlink= |title=The Media and the Rwanda Genocide |url=http://www.idrc.ca/EN/Resources/Publications/Pages/IDRCBookDetails.aspx?PublicationID=131 |accessdate=19 March 2013 |year=2007 |publisher=Pluto Press, Fountain Publishers, IDRC |location= |isbn=0-74532-625-0 |page=98 }}</ref> ''animateur'' of RTLM and the ''animateur'' with by far the most airtime. Segments by Habimana accounted for approximately 33% of RTLM airtime.<ref>{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=Allan (Ed.) |authorlink= |title=Kimani, Mary: RTLM: the Medium that Became a Tool for Mass Murder. In "The Media and the Rwanda Genocide" |url=http://www.idrc.ca/EN/Resources/Publications/Pages/IDRCBookDetails.aspx?PublicationID=131 |accessdate=19 March 2013 |year=2007 |publisher=Pluto Press, Fountain Publishers, IDRC |location= |isbn=0-74532-625-0 |page=116 }}</ref> Habimana (and RTLM) was known for visiting roadblocks on-air and interviewing the [[Interahamwe]] militia present in order to interact with his listeners first-hand.<ref>{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=Allan (Ed.) |authorlink= |title=The Media and the Rwanda Genocide |url=http://www.idrc.ca/EN/Resources/Publications/Pages/IDRCBookDetails.aspx?PublicationID=131 |accessdate=19 March 2013 |year=2007 |publisher=Pluto Press, Fountain Publishers, IDRC |location= |isbn=0-74532-625-0 |page=99 }}</ref> Habimana routinely announced exact whereabouts, names and license plate numbers of alleged [[Rwandan Patriotic Front|RPF]] accomplices,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cotton |first1=Cassandra |year=2007 |title='Where Radio is King:' Rwanda's Hate Radio and the Lessons Learned. |journal=Atlantic International Studies Journal |volume= |issue= |pages=4–11 |publisher= |doi= |url=http://atlismta.org/online-journals/0607-journal-gender-environment-and-human-rights/where-radio-is-king/#_ftn43 |accessdate=17 March 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rwandafile.com/rtlm/pdf/rtlm0002.pdf Official UN transcript; ICTR-99-52-T; P103/2B, pg.4]</ref><ref>[http://www.rwandafile.com/rtlm/pdf/rtlm0122x.pdf Official UN transcript; ICTR-99-52-T; P103/122, pg.1]</ref> inciting targeted violence and often murder on the named individuals by groups such as the [[Impuzamugambi]] and [[Interahamwe]] militias.
At a pre-genocide court hearing on March 15, 1994, for "the incitement of citizens against each other", Habimana described RTLM broadcasters as "small fish" compared to RTLM executives such as [[Ferdinand Nahimana]].<ref>The Prosecutor v. Ferdinand Nahimana, Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, Hassan Ngeze (Judgement and Sentence), ICTR-99-52-T, pg. 176, International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR), 3 December 2003, available at: http://www.refworld.org/docid/404468bc2.html [accessed 21 December 2017]</ref>
Habimana allegedly died of [[AIDS]] in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Li |first1=Darryl |last2= |first2= |year=2004 |title=Echoes of violence: Considerations on radio and genocide in Rwanda. |journal=Journal of Genocide Research |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=25 |publisher= |doi= 10.1080/1462352042000194683|url=https://www.academia.edu/362149/Echoes_of_Violence_Considerations_on_Radio_and_Genocide_In_Rwanda |accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> before 2002.<ref name= "hirondelle 01" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2015}} The '''Kisan Mazdoor Praja Party''' was a political party of India. Established in 1951, it merged with the [[Socialist Party (India)|Socialist Party]] to form the [[Praja Socialist Party]] in the following year.
==History== In June, 1951 [[Indian National Congress]] dissidents led by [[Jivatram Kripalani]] founded the KMPP. Its 2 leaders : [[Prafulla Chandra Ghosh]] and [[Tanguturi Prakasam]], had been chief ministers of [[West Bengal]] and [[Madras Province|Madras]] respectively.<ref name="Chandra" /> It contested the very first parliamentary elections in 1951 in India. The party contested in 16 states and won nine seats in the [[Lok Sabha]], including six in [[Mysore state]],<ref>http://parliamentofindia.nic.in/ls/lok01/state/01lsmd.htm</ref> and one in [[Madras state]], Delhi and [[Vindhya Pradesh]] province.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eci.gov.in/StatisticalReports/ElectionStatistics.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218010942/http://www.eci.gov.in/StatisticalReports/ElectionStatistics.asp |archivedate=18 December 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.assembly.tn.gov.in/archive/Resumes/review_01assly/table01.pdf</ref> and 5.8% of the votes. But it won only 77 seats in the state legislative assemblies.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} In September, 1952 it merged with the Socialist Party to form the Praja Socialist Party.<ref name="Chandra">Chandra, Bipan & others (2000). ''India after Independence 1947-2000'', New Delhi:Penguin Books, {{ISBN|0-14-027825-7}}, p.201</ref><ref>http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2004-04-03/india/28332682_1_janata-party-political-parties-parties-today</ref>
==See also== *[[Indian National Congress breakaway parties]] *[[Haripada Chattopadhyay]]

revision.text:
The '''League of Nations Society''' was a political group devoted to campaigning for an international organisation of nations, with the aim of preventing war.
The society was founded in 1915 by [[Leonard Courtney, 1st Baron Courtney of Penwith|Baron Courtney]] and [[Willoughby Dickinson, 1st Baron Dickinson|Willoughby Dickinson]], both members of the British [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]], and [[Charles Cripps, 1st Baron Parmoor|Baron Parmoor]], a member of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]. The group campaigned for the establishment of the [[League of Nations]], its interest mostly motivated by pacifism, and opposition to [[World War I]].<ref name="cline">{{cite book |last1=Cline |first1=Catherine Ann |title=Recruits to Labour |date=1963 |publisher=Syracuse University Press |location=Syracuse, New York |page=16–17}}</ref>
The society was influenced by the proposals of the [[Bryce Group]], and many of that group's members also held membership of the society. However, it differed from the Bryce Group in proposing that the future international league should be able to impose sanctions in order to enforce arbitration decisions, not just to compel nations to take disputes into arbitration.<ref name="cline" />
The society grew quickly, appointing [[Margery Spring Rice]] as its secretary,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Working_class_Wives.html?id=tt2EGwAACAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Working-class Wives: Their Health and Conditions|last=Spring Rice|first=Margery Garrett|date=1 January 1939|publisher=Penguin Books|language=en}}</ref> and within a couple of years had several thousand members.<ref name="cline" /> By 1917, [[Woodrow Wilson]] supported the principle of a League of Nations, and less radical supporters of the idea formed the League of Free Nations Association. In 1918, the two organisations merged, forming the [[League of Nations Union]].<ref name="cline" />

<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:Brustad.jpg|thumb|120px|right|Current Minister of Health and Care Services, Sylvia Brustad]] --> The '''Royal Norwegian Ministry of Health and Care Services''' (''Helse- og omsorgsdepartementet'') is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] government ministry in charge of health policy, [[public health]], [[health care]] services and health legislation in Norway.
More specifically the Ministry of Health and Care Services has the superior responsibility for providing the [[population]] with adequate health care services, including health promotion, based upon the principle of [[egalitarianism|equality]] and health care services independent of habitation and financial circumstances.
The Minister of Health and Care Services is the head of the Ministry, and its political leader. The position is currently being held by [[Bent Høie]]. [[Norwegian_Board_of_Health|The Norwegian Board of Health]] is a national government institution under the Ministry of Health and Care Services.
==Subsidiaries== The ministry owns the four regional health authorities in Norway: * [[Central Norway Regional Health Authority]] * [[Northern Norway Regional Health Authority]] * [[Southern and Eastern Norway Regional Health Authority]] * [[Western Norway Regional Health Authority]]
It also is supreme of the following [[government agency|government agencies]]: * [[Norwegian Directorate for Health and Social Affairs]] * [[Norwegian Board of Health Supervision]] * [[Norwegian Institute of Public Health]] * [[Norwegian System of Compensation to Patients]] * [[Norwegian Medicines Agency]] * [[National Institute for Alcohol and Drug Research]] * [[Norwegian Scientific Committee for Food Safety]] * [[Norwegian Radiation Protection Authority]] * [[Norwegian Labour and Welfare Service]] * [[Norwegian Food Safety Authority]] * [[Norwegian Biotechnology Advisory Board]] * [[Statens helsepersonellnemnd]] * [[Norwegian Patients' Injury Compensation Board]] * [[Norwegian Governmental Appeal Board regarding medical treatment abroad]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051025083014/http://odin.dep.no/hod/english/bn.html Ministry of Health and Care Services] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051123160410/http://www.fhi.no/eway/default0.asp?e=0&pid=225 Norwegian Institute of Public Health] * [http://www.helsetilsynet.no/templates/sectionpage____5499.aspx Norwegian Board of Health Supervision] * [http://www.shdir.no/portal/page?_pageid=134,112387&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&language=english Norwegian Directorate for Health and Social Affairs] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051025082818/http://www.legemiddelverket.no/eng/default.htm Norwegian Medicines Agency]

[[Economic liberalism]][http://formiche.net/2017/11/02/programma-radicali-forza-eur Programma dei Radicali e di Forza Europa] |position = [[Centrism|Centre]] |national = [[Centre-left coalition]] |european = |international = |europarl = |colours = {{Color box|{{More Europe/meta/color}}|border=darkgray}} [[Gold (color)|Gold]] |seats1_title = [[Chamber of Deputies (Italy)|Chamber of Deputies]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|3|630|hex={{More Europe/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = [[Senate of the Republic (Italy)|Senate]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|1|315|hex={{More Europe/meta/color}}}} |seats3_title = [[European Parliament]] |seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|73|hex={{More Europe/meta/color}}}} |seats4_title = [[Composition of Regional Councils of Italy|Regional Councils]] |seats4 = {{Composition bar|6|897|hex={{More Europe/meta/color}}}} |website = [http://piueuropa.eu www.piueuropa.eu] |country = Italy }} '''More Europe''' ({{lang-it|Più Europa}} or ''+Europa'', '''+E''') is a [[liberalism|liberal]], [[pro-Europeanism|pro-European]] and [[Centrism|centrist]]{{Cite web|url=http://parties-and-elections.eu/italy.html|title=Parties and Elections in Europe|last=Nordsieck|first=Wolfram|website=parties-and-elections.eu|access-date=2018-11-16}} [[list of political parties in Italy|political party in Italy]], within the [[centre-left coalition]]. The party is led by [[Emma Bonino]], leader of the [[Italian Radicals]] and former minister. ==History== More Europe was launched in November 2017, seeking to participate in the [[Italian general election, 2018|2018 general election]] within the [[centre-left coalition]] centred on the [[Democratic Party (Italy)|Democratic Party]] (PD).[http://www.huffingtonpost.it/2017/11/13/pd-radicali-incontro-al-nazareno-in-vista-delle-elezioni_a_23275409 Pd-Radicali, incontro al Nazareno in vista delle elezioni] The founding members were two liberal and distinctively pro-Europeanist parties: the [[Italian Radicals]] (RI), whose leading members included [[Emma Bonino]] (a former minister of International Commerce and Foreign Affairs), [[Riccardo Magi]] and [[Marco Cappato]], and [[Forza Europa (2017)|Forza Europa]] (FE), led by [[Benedetto Della Vedova]], a former Radical elected in [[Italian general election, 2013|2013]] with [[Future and Freedom]] (FLI) and later transitated through [[Civic Choice]] (SC). The RI and FE were joined by individual members of the [[Civics and Innovators]] (CI) sub-group in the [[Chamber of Deputies (Italy)|Chamber of Deputies]], formed by former SC members (two CI deputies, [[Andrea Mazziotti]] and [[Stefano Dambruoso]], were already involved with FE). [[Angelo Bonelli]], coordinator of the [[Federation of the Greens]], had earlier proposed to the Radicals a joint list together with [[Giuliano Pisapia]]'s [[Progressive Camp]] (CP) named "Ecology, Europe, Rights".[http://www.repubblica.it/politica/2017/11/23/news/radicali_italiani_lista_europeista-181892110/ Radicali italiani, ecco la lista europeista di Bonino e Della Vedova] However, Pisapia announced that he would not run in the election and declared CP's experience over, while the Radicals organised +E. In early January 2018 Bonino and Della Vedova announced that +E would run as a stand-alone list, due to technical reasons associated with the new electoral laws.[http://www.corriere.it/politica/18_gennaio_01/elezioni-2018-bonino-la-lista-europa-costretta-correre-sola-elezioni-03d7e7d8-ef22-11e7-97e1-31c2bf5f7cef.shtml Bonino: «La lista +Europa costretta a correre da sola alle elezioni»] While the PD leadership was trying to find a solution to those problems,[http://ildubbio.news/ildubbio/2018/01/03/elezioni-renzi-speriamo-di-risolvere-problemi-con-piu-europa Elezioni, Renzi: Speriamo di risolvere I problemi con Più Europa] on 4 January, [[Bruno Tabacci]], leader of the [[Centrism|centrist]], mostly [[Christian democracy|Christian-democratic]] and also pro-Europeanist [[Democratic Centre (Italy)|Democratic Centre]] (CD), announced that his party would join the coalition +E, in alliance with the PD, in order to overcome those issues.[http://www.corriere.it/politica/18_gennaio_04/tabacci-salva-lista-bonino-il-4-marzo-europa-ci-sara-20c7f420-f15f-11e7-b33d-56f05ccceb4d.shtml Tabacci salva la lista di Bonino: «Il 4 marzo +Europa ci sarà»][http://www.lastampa.it/2018/01/04/italia/politica/elezioni-bonino-grazie-tabacci-europa-sar-lunica-lista-pienamente-europeista-GJWpji62WisnrGz7MmSEMP/pagina.html Elezioni, Tabacci salva la lista di Emma Bonino: “Niente firme, il 4 marzo ci saremo”][http://www.repubblica.it/politica/2018/01/04/news/rosatellum_bonino_imbroglio_battaglia_giurisdizionale_elezioni_2018_legge_elettorale-185796021 Rosatellum, Tabacci: "Esenzione simbolo Centro Democratico a disposizione per lista Bonino"] Later in January, +E was enlarged also to the [[Progressive Area]] (AP), a small left-wing party emerged from the dissolution of the [[Progressive Camp]] (CP),[http://www.piumezzogiorno.it/8944/politica/centrosinistra-area-progressista-europa.html Centrosinistra, intesa raggiunta tra Area Progressista e +Europa][http://www.gazzettinodisalerno.it/joomla/politica/item/16788-elezioni-area-progressista-a-sostegno-di-europa Elezioni, Area Progressista a sostegno di +Europa] a would-be party launched by [[Giuliano Pisapia]] (Pisapia did not join and AP itself would never be a full member of +E). Also in January, Bonino officially announced the alliance with the centre-left.[http://www.repubblica.it/politica/2018/01/20/news/gentiloni_correra_nel_collegio_uninominale_roma_1_-186907642/?ref=RHPPLF-BH-I0-C8-P2-S1.8-T1 Il centrosinistra al voto con una coalizione a 4: Pd con +Europa, Civica Popolare e Insieme] The list won 2.6% of the vote in the election, falling short of the 3% threshold, but had three elects in single-seat constituencies (Bonino to the Senate, Magi and Tabacci to the Chamber) and one among Italians abroad ([[Alessandro Fusacchia]], a Radical, in the European constituency). In July 2018 +E started to organise itself as a full-fledged party. It was decided that a committee, presided by [[Gianfranco Spadaccia]] (a long-time Radical), would lead +E until the founding congress, scheduled for January 2019. '''NAIBER''' is an [[acronym]] for '''non-accelerating inflation buffer employment ratio''' and refers to a systemic proposal for an in-built inflation control mechanism devised by economists [[Bill Mitchell (economist)|Bill Mitchell]]<ref>W.F. Mitchell (1998) "The Buffer Stock Employment Model - Full Employment without a NAIRU" ''[[Journal of Economic Issues]]'' 32(2), 547-55</ref> and [[Warren Mosler]],<ref>W.B. Mosler (1997-98) "Full Employment and Price Stability" ''[[Journal of Post Keynesian Economics]]'', 20(2), 167-182</ref> and advocated by [[Modern Money Theory]] as replacement for [[NAIRU|NAIRU (non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment)]]. The concept of NAIBER is related to the idea of a [[Job Guarantee]] aimed to create [[full employment]] and price stability, by having the state promise to hire unemployed workers as an [[employer of last resort]] (ELR).<ref name="ref1">[[L. Randall Wray]], [http://neweconomicperspectives.blogspot.com/2009/08/job-guarantee.html "Job Guarantee"]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.it/books?id=tdQMAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA328&lpg=PA328&dq=wray+%22naiber%22&source=bl&ots=fisPFxi1W3&sig=BUpG2T-YLizR6AlhHR1Y9LwKFuQ&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivqYSpuezZAhWGtxQKHbjhCBkQ6AEINjAC#v=onepage&q=wray%20%22naiber%22&f=false Phil Lawn: “Globalisation, Economic Transition and the Environment -Forging a Path to Sustainable Development”, Edward Elgar Publishing, 2013]</ref>
==Description== If the [[Phillips curve]] displays [[hysteresis#Economics|hysteresis]] - that is, if episodes of high unemployment raise the NAIRU - the NAIRU analysis is especially problematic.<ref>{{Citation |last=Ball, Laurence |title=Hysteresis in Unemployment: Old and New Evidence |url = http://www.nber.org/papers/w14818.pdf |year=2009}} </ref> This could happen, for example, if unemployed workers lose skills so that employers prefer to bid up of the wages of existing workers when demand increases, rather than hiring the unemployed. Economists as [[Abba Lerner]] and [[Hyman Minsky]] have argued that a similar effect can be achieved without the human costs of unemployment via a [[Job Guarantee]] (JG), where rather than being unemployed, those who cannot find work in the private sector should be employed by the government. This theory, and the policy of the JG replaces the NAIRU with the NAIBER (non-accelerating inflation buffer employment ratio).<ref>{{Citation |last=William Mitchell, J. Muysken |title=Full employment abandoned: shifting sands and policy failures |url = https://books.google.com/?id=caEl9oAI4XoC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q |year=2008 |isbn=1-85898-507-2|publisher =Edward Elgar Publishing}} </ref>
The ''buffer employment ratio'' (BER) is the ratio of JG employment to total employment. The BER conditions the overall rate of wage demands. When the BER is high, real wage demands will be correspondingly lower. If inflation exceeds the government’s announced target, tighter fiscal and monetary policy would be triggered to increase the BER, which entails workers transferring from the inflating sector to the fixed price JG sector. Ultimately this attenuates the inflation spiral. So instead of a buffer stock of unemployed being used to discipline the distributional struggle, the JG policy achieves this via compositional shifts in employment. Replacing the current ''non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment'' ([[NAIRU]]), the BER that results in stable inflation is called the ''non-accelerating inflation buffer employment ratio'' (NAIBER). It is a full employment steady state JG level, which is dependent on a range of factors including the path of the economy.<ref>W.F. Mitchell and J. Muysken (2008). ''[http://www.e-elgar.co.uk/Bookentry_Main.lasso?id=1188 Full Employment Abandoned: Shifting Sands and Policy failures],''. Edward Elgar: [[Cheltenham]]. Revised: January 2009 [http://arno.unimaas.nl/show.cgi?fid=14937]</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{expert needed|1=Sweden|date=March 2018}} {{primary sources|date=March 2018}} {{refimprove|date=March 2018}} {{update|date=March 2018}} }} There are 15 '''parliamentary committees in the [[Riksdag]]''', [[Sweden]]'s parliament. Each committee is made up of seventeen elected MPs, with at least one member from each political party.
==Current committees== ;Civil Affairs :The Committee on Civil Affairs was formed on 1 October 2006. This committee overtook issues that were previously handled by the Committee on Civil Law ({{lang|sv|Lagutskottet}}) and the Committee on Housing ({{lang|sv|Bostadsutskottet}}). ;Constitution :The first Committee on the Constitution was established in the [[Riksdag of the Estates]] in May 1809. The committee played a decisive role in bringing about a new [[Instrument of Government (1809)|Instrument of Government]], which was adopted on 6 June 1809. The existence of a Committee on the Constitution and other parliamentary committees was further regulated in the current Instrument of Government from 1974. :The committee prepares matters concerning the [[Constitution of Sweden|Fundamental Laws of the Realm]] ({{lang|sv|Rikets grundlagar}}) and the [[Constitution of Sweden|Riksdag Act]] ({{lang|sv|Riksdagsordningen}}) and certain other legislation. The current chairman is [[Andreas Norlén]] of the [[Moderate Party]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Andreas Norlén (Mod) - Riksdagen|url=http://www.riksdagen.se/en/members-and-parties/member/andreas-norlen_46bb7675-2a79-4efa-8a0d-c513ad32a47d|website=www.riksdagen.se|accessdate=26 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> ;Cultural Affairs ;Defence ;Education ;Environment and Agriculture ;Finance :The current chair of the Finance Committee is [[Fredrik Olovsson]] of the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party|Social Democrats]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Fredrik Olovsson (SocDem) - Riksdagen|url=http://www.riksdagen.se/en/members-and-parties/member/fredrik-olovsson_bc5c4354-fca3-4071-8096-acd9b7b1d09a|website=www.riksdagen.se|accessdate=26 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> ;Foreign Affairs :The current chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs is [[Kenneth G. Forslund]] of the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party|Social Democrats]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Kenneth G Forslund (SocDem) - Riksdagen|url=http://www.riksdagen.se/en/members-and-parties/member/kenneth-g-forslund_f1484855-05d7-498f-8872-5a0c33ad535b|website=www.riksdagen.se|accessdate=26 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> ;Health and Welfare ;Justice :The Committee on Justice was established in 1971. The committee prepares matters concerning the [[Judiciary|judicial system]], the [[Penal code|Penal Code]] ({{lang|sv|Brottsbalken}}), and the [[Code of Judicial Procedure]] ({{lang|sv|Rättegångsbalken}}). ;Labour Market ;Social Insurance ;Taxation ;Transport and Communications; ;Health and Welfare
==Former committees== There are six committees that no longer meet: * Secret Committee * Committee on the State * Committee on General Affairs and the Economy * Committee on the Accords * Committee on Civil Law * Committee on Housing
==See also== *[[War Delegation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{official|http://www.riksdagen.se/en/committees/the-15-parliamentary-committees/}}

Rojo, Arximiro (1987). ''As Mocedades Galeguistas (Historia dun compromiso).'' [[Vigo]]: Galaxia. {{ISBN|84-7154-579-9}}.7 | position = [[Big tent]] (1931-1935)
[[Left-wing|Left-wing]] to [[Centrism|centre]] (1935-1950) | religion = | national = | international = | european = | europarl = | affiliation1_title = | affiliation1 = | seats1_title = [[Congreso de los Diputados]] ([[Spanish general election, 1936|1936]]) | seats1 = {{Composition bar|4|470|hex=blue}} | colors = Blue and white. | symbol = | flag = | website = | state = Galicia | country = Spain | country_dab1 = | parties_dab1 = | elections_dab1 = | country2 = | country_dab2 = | parties_dab2 = | elections_dab2 = | footnotes = }} The '''Partido Galeguista''' ('''Galicianist Party''') was a [[Galician nationalism|Galician nationalist]] party founded in December 1931. It achieved notoriety during the time of the [[Spanish Second Republic]]. The PG grouped a number of historical [[Galicia (Spain)|Galician]] intellectuals, and was fundamental in the elaboration of the [[Galician Statute of Autonomy (1936)|Galician Statute of Autonomy]]. ==Origins== In December 1931 the ''{{ill|Partido Galeguista de Pontevedra|gl|Partido Galeguista de Pontevedra}}'' (Galicianist Party of Pontevedra), directed by [[Castelao]] and [[Alexandre Bóveda]], called for a General Nationalist Assembly in order to create an all-Galician nationalist party. A total of 32 [[Galicianism (Galicia)|Galicianist]] organizations attended, including the ''[[Irmandades da Fala]]'' (Brotherhoods of the Language) and the ''[[Partido Nazonalista Republicán de Ourense]]'' (Republican Nationalist Party of Ourense), among others. The PG was a plural party hosting different political tendencies, and where internal tensions were not uncommon. The PG initially embraced: * Right-wing conservatives, who rejected the idea of forming alliances with left-wing parties. These were individuals such as [[Vicente Risco]], [[Antón Vilar Ponte|Vilar Ponte]], [[Xosé Filgueira Valverde|Filgueira Valverde]] * Liberals, such as [[Otero Pedrayo]], [[Ramón Plácido Castro|Plácido Castro]] * Left-wing sympathizers, such as [[Alexandre Bóveda]], [[Castelao]], [[Carvalho Calero]], [[Ramón Suárez Picallo|Suárez Picallo]], [[Johán Vicente Viqueira]], [[Álvaro das Casas]], [[Ramón Vilar Ponte]], * Supporters of the Galician [[secession]], such as [[Fuco Gómez]] or the [[Buenos Aires]] organization ''Sociedade Nazionalista Gallega Pondal'' * Non-aligned: [[Álvaro Cunqueiro]], [[Florentino López Cuevillas|López Cuevillas]] ==Political ideas== The political programme of the PG revolved around the ideals established by the ''[[Irmandades da Fala]]'',Beramendi and Núñez Seixas (1996:148) that is, considering Galicia as a cultural unit entitled to political [[self-determination]]. In order to achieve this the minimum required was forming a Galician Parliament and a Galician Government. It also aimed at eliminating [[clientelism]], supporting [[anti-imperialism]] and equal rights for the women. Furthermore, the PG claimed for the suppression of the provincial governments (perceived as a redundant administrative structure) and the establishment of the parish as an official territorial tier. Official status for the [[Galician language]] and [[agrarian reform]] were also in the agenda. Independence was never a priority for the PG, as independentists were a minority within the party. It was thought that Galicia could operate within the framework of a Spanish [[federal republic]]. Yet, War and the impossibility to establish such a federal republic led to disappointment. In a later stage, around 1944, PG's president and intellectual leader, Castelao, began to consider the option of full independence.See full article on [[Castelao]] Members of the PG expressed a strong [[pro-Europeanism]],Castelao often commented on his wish to "one day see the emergence of a 'United States of Europe' " (''Sempre en Galiza'', 1944). situating the party ahead of its time on this issue. They also supported the strengthening of the [[League of Nations]] (predecessor of the UN) as a tool to solve international conflicts. In 1933, the PG successfully requested the admission of Galicia into the League as a [[stateless nation]]. Those negotiations were conducted by [[Ramón Plácido Castro|Plácido Castro]].[http://www.vieiros.com/nova/69052/setembro-de-1933-galiza-unha-nacion-en-europa][http://www.igadi.org/fundacion_placido_castro/placido_ramon_castro_del_rio_us.htm] ==Consolidation== In 1932 the PG works alongside the ''Partido Republicano Gallego'' (Galician Republican Party) and ''Acción Republicana'' (Republican Action) in the drafting and promotion of the [[Galician Statute of Autonomy (1936)|Statute of Autonomy]]. The PG negotiates a number of pacts with local parties and in 1933 it takes part in the local elections, obtaining a single local deputy for [[Ourense]]. This issue opens the debate in the PG, as some wanted to seek alliances with republican parties (left-wing), something which was frontally rejected by the conservatives. The conservative pressure within the party forces PG to take part at the [[Spanish general election, 1933|1933 general Spanish elections]] on its own. The 106,000 votes obtained are not enough to grant a seat at the [[Spanish Parliament]]. Furthermore, the new conservative Spanish government halts the development of the Statute of Autonomy, bans PG's newspaper ''A Nosa Terra'', and relocates [[Castelao]] and [[Alexandre Bóveda|Bóveda]] far from Galicia (they were civil servants). In its Third Assembly, January 1934, the PG eventually decides to ally with left-wing republican parties, with the opposition of [[Vicente Risco]]. This decision is ratified in the Fourth Assembly, April 1935, this time with the opposition of [[Otero Pedrayo]]. Thus, the conservative sector leaves the PG to found ''[[Dereita Galeguista]]'' (Galicianist Right-Wing). The PG then openly becomes a left-wing party. ==''Frente Popular''== In June 1935 the PG initiates negotiations with [[Republican Left (Spain)|''Izquierda Republicana'']] (Republican Left), and in January 1936 the PG decides to integrate itself in the [[Popular Front (Spain)|''Frente Popular'']] (Popular Front). Hence, the PG presented five Galicianist candidates to the [[Spanish general election, 1936|Spanish general election of 1936]], namely: Castelao, Bóveda, Xerardo Álvarez Gallego, Ramón Suárez Picallo and Antón Villar Ponte. In the province of [[Lugo (province)|Lugo]] the PG ran on its own, since specific pacts for that province could not be formalized, thus obtaining no representatives. However, out of the five candidates the PG obtains three seats in the Spanish Parliament. These are Castelao, Súarez Picallo and Vilar Ponte, with a combined total of some 287,000 votes. As a consequence, in June 1936 the Statute of Autonomy is put to the vote with the help of the ''Frente Popular'', and the "yes" wins with an overwhelming majority. ==Civil War== Following the revolt of general [[Francisco Franco]] in July 1936, and the start of the [[Spanish Civil War]], normal political life comes to an end. Galicia soon falls under the control of Franco's [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist]] troops and PG members are prosecuted. Some of them are captured and executed, such as Johán Carballeira, Ánxel Casal, Manuel Lustres Rivas, Camilo Díaz Baliño, Víctor Casas or one of the main leaders of the party, [[Alexandre Bóveda]]. Others are forced into exile, like the president of the party, [[Castelao]], who was in [[Madrid]] when the war started and managed to flee. In 1937 the PG establishes a delegation in [[Barcelona]], still a republican area, and publishes the magazine ''Nova Galicia'' between April 1937 and July 1938. Castelao and Suárez Picallo call for the unity of all democratic forces in Spain to preserve the Republic, while maintaining the Galicianist ideals. In 1938, after the fall of Barcelona, the Galicianists in the area move to France and from there to South America. ==The underground== As soon as the Civil War ended in 1939, Galicianists tried to get in touch again in order to rebuild the party in Galicia. The PG appeared in the underground in July 1943, when 19 members meet in Coruxo and decide to form a temporary executive committee, including Manuel Gómez Román, Otero Pedrayo and Plácido Castro. Yet, in this new period, [[Francisco Fernández del Riego]] and [[Ramón Piñeiro]] had the most active role. One of the priorities was to establish contacts with the rest of the Galician opposition to the [[Spain under Franco|Francoist regime]], and also with [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] and [[Catalonia|Catalan]] nationalists. In 1944 the PG forms together with the [[Spanish Socialist Party]], [[Confederacion Nacional del Trabajo|CNT]], [[Union General de Trabajadores|UGT]], and other trade unions, the ''Junta Gallega de Alianza Democrática'' (Galician Union for the Democratic Alliance). Ramón Piñeiro was detained in 1946. Fermín Penzol took responsibility for keeping contact with the other organizations. With the release of Piñeiro in 1949, and in the light that the underground activity did not produce any palpable results,Fernández del Riego (1990:190) the PG led by Piñeiro decides to prioritise the defence of Galician culture, gradually abandoning the political activity. This was severely criticised by the Galicianists in exile. Hence, the foundation of the ''{{ill|Galaxia publishing house|lt=Galaxia|gl|Editorial Galaxia}}'' publishing house, in 1950 marks the self-dissolution of the PG in Galicia. From that date militants in Galicia take part in the new cultural strategy, which revolved around ''Galaxia''. ==The PG in the Americas== In 1932 a branch of the PG was created in [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina. This was the ''Organizacion Nazionalista Repubricana Galega'' (Galician Republican Nationalist Organization). It had 150 members and was led by Rodolfo Prada. At the time of the Civil War it changes its name to ''Grupo Galeguista de Bos Aires'' (Galicianist Group of Buenos Aires). In 1941 it takes the name of ''Irmandade Galega'' (Galician Brotherhood). In 1942, with the massive arrival or Galician expatriates to Buenos Aires (including Castelao), this same group relaunches the PG newspaper ''A Nosa Terra''. In 1944, ''Irmandade Galega'', with the support of Castelao, establish the ''Consello de Galiza'', a sort of Galician government in exile. There was also a branch of the PG in [[Uruguay]], named ''Irmandade Galeguista do Uruguai'', led my Manuel Meilán. In 1949 the PG only had a total of some 200 active militants scattered around Buenos Aires and other Argentinian cities, [[Montevideo]] (Uruguay), [[Mexico]] and [[Havana]] (Cuba). With the cessation of the political activities of the PG in Galicia, the PG abroad quickly faded out, especially after the death of Castelao, the historical leader of the party, in 1950. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Beramendi, X.G. and Núñez Seixas, X.M. (1996): ''O nacionalismo galego''. A Nosa Terra, Vigo * Beramendi, X.G. (2007): ''De provincia a nación. Historia do galeguismo político''. Xerais, Vigo * Castro, X. (1985): ''O galeguismo na encrucillada republicana''. Deputación provincial, Ourense * Fernández del Riego, F. (1990): ''O río do tempo. Unha historia vivida''. Ediciós do Castro, Sada, 1990 ==See also== *[[Galician Statute of Autonomy of 1981]] *[[Castelao]] *[[Alexandre Bóveda]] *[[Galicianism (Galicia)|Galicia]] *[[Galician nationalism]] *[[History of Galicia]] {{Galician nationalism |state=collapsed}} [[Category:Political parties established in 1931]] [[Category:Political parties in Galicia (Spain)]] [[Category:Secessionist organizations in Europe]] [[Category:Regionalist parties in Spain]] [[Category:Defunct nationalist parties in Spain]] [[Category:Galician nationalism]] [[Category:1931 establishments in Spain]]

{{Infobox software | name = Pombola | logo = | screenshot = Mzalendo_Kenya_screenshot.jpg | caption = Mzalendo, the Kenyan website, running on Pombola | developer = | released = 2013 | latest release version = | latest release date = | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | language = | programming language = | license = [[Affero General Public License|AGPLv3]]<ref name="pmlicensing">{{cite web |url=https://github.com/mysociety/pombola/blob/master/LICENSE.txt |title=Pombola - GitHub}}</ref> }}
'''Pombola'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mysociety.org/projects/parliamentarymonitoring/pombola/|title=Pombola / mySociety|publisher=}}</ref> is [[free open source software]] by [[mySociety]] for running a [[parliamentary monitoring website]].
Pombola’s development was funded by the [[Omidyar Network]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://transparency.globalvoicesonline.org/project/mzalendo|title=Mzalendo - Technology for Transparency Network|publisher=}}</ref> to relaunch the [[Mzalendo]] site in [[Kenya]].
The [[IndigoTrust]] funded roll-out to further countries, with a particular focus on the provision of [[Transparency (behavior)#Politics|transparency]] websites for [[sub-Saharan Africa]].<ref name="Ind">{{cite web|url=https://indigotrust.org.uk/2013/01/21/3571/|title=Grant Awarded to mySociety|first=|last=mattindigo|date=21 January 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
Among other features, Pombola allows for websites that publish parliamentary transcripts, hold a database of information about politicians, and, using the mySociety software [[MySociety#poplus components|MapIt]], can match a user’s home location to their [[Electoral district|constituency]].
The site was inspired by [[TheyWorkForYou]] - mySociety's UK parliamentary monitoring site.<ref>{{cite web|title=MySociety: Pombola|url=https://www.mysociety.org/democracy/pombola/|accessdate=6 August 2016}}</ref>
== Sites running on Pombola == * Ghana - Odekro<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odekro.org/|title=Home - Odekro|publisher=}}</ref> * Kenya - Mzalendo<ref>{{cite web|url=http://info.mzalendo.com|title=Mzalendo|publisher=}}</ref> * Nigeria - Shine Your Eye<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shineyoureye.org/|title=ShineYourEye|publisher=}}</ref> * South Africa - People's Assembly<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pa.org.za/|title=People's Assembly|publisher=}}</ref> * Zimbabwe - Kuvakazim<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kuvakazim.com/|title=Home :: KuvakaZim|publisher=}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

The '''Prime Minister's Department''' ({{lang-ms|Jabatan Perdana Menteri}}, abbreviated '''JPM''') is a federal government ministry in Malaysia. Its objective is "determining the services of all divisions are implemented according to policy, legislation / regulations and current guidelines". It is headed by the [[Prime Minister of Malaysia]] followed by other [[Minister in the Prime Minister's Department]]. The Department consists of the Prime Minister's Office, the Deputy Prime Minister's Office and more than 50 other government agencies and entities.<ref name="pmo">{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.my/?menu=page&page=1670|title=Government Directory: Prime Minister's Department|date=8 July 2011|publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Malaysia|accessdate=28 July 2011}}</ref> The Prime Minister's Department was established in July 1957.<ref name="history">{{cite web|url=http://www.jpm.gov.my/userfiles/file/1957-1966.pdf|title=History of Prime Minister's Department|publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Malaysia|accessdate=28 July 2011}}</ref> Its headquarters are in [[Perdana Putra]], [[Putrajaya]].
==Structure== Formerly known as General Administration, Prime Minister’s Department. The Department was organized into an Innovation and Human Resource Management Division, a Finance Division, a Development Division, an Accounts Division, a Management Services Division, an Internal Audit Division, a Corporate Communications Unit Division, an Events Management Division and a Legal Advisor Office Division. All nine (9) divisions are reporting to the Senior Deputy Secretary-General and assisted by the two Deputy Secretary-General which are Deputy Secretary-General (Financial and Development) and Deputy Secretary-General (Management).

{{multiple issues| {{advert|date=July 2013}} {{notability|Products|date=July 2013}} {{Orphan|date=July 2013}} }}
==Introduction== Push Video is an active [[notification system]] with the function of sending video. The technology enables notifications show up on [[mobile phone]]s when uncommon events occurs. It works with [[Surveillance|surveillance system]] like [[IP camera]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avtech.com.tw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=225&Itemid=446 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023183202/http://www.avtech.com.tw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=225&Itemid=446 |archivedate=2013-10-23 |df= }}</ref> The notification allows people to check the video playback on their devices, includes Galaxy, [[iPhone]], [[iPad]] and other [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices.<ref>https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=push.lite.avtech.com</ref> The Push Video is triggered by the [[EagleEyes]] and IPmotion applications; being one of their main functions. It has been applied to [[Avtech Corp.|AVTECH’s]] and Hunt Electronic full range products.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avtech.com.tw/index.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130724051638/http://www.avtech.com.tw/index.php |archivedate=2013-07-24 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.hunt.com.tw</ref>
==History== The naming of Push Video starts from the "Push mail" of [[BlackBerry]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://event.taiwanmobile.com/blackberry/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605064310/http://event.taiwanmobile.com/blackberry/ |archivedate=2013-06-05 |df= }}</ref> The functions between them are similar. Users do not have to log into the server to check if there is incoming messages. The server will send the notifications automatically to the users to notify them.
==Functions== The function works base on [[IP camera]]. Once the built-in or external sensor of IP cameras is triggered, it will set up the alarm. The system can automatically send the video through [[WiFi|Wifi]], [[2G]], [[3G]], [[4G]] to the devices of the users once the alarm is triggered. The video clip will be sent no later than five seconds, starting from the previous three seconds of the occurred events and ends at the next forty seconds after the event occurs.

{{Infobox company |name = The Scottish Crop Research Institute |logo = Scri.gif |founded = 1987 |type = Registered Charity |predecessor = Scottish Horticultural Research Institute
Scottish Plant Breeding Station |successor = [[James Hutton Institute|The James Hutton Institute]] |location_city = [[Dundee]] |location_country = [[Scotland]] |homepage = {{URL|www.scri.ac.uk}} |key_people = Peter Gregory |defunct = {{End date|2011|03|31}} |fate = Merged |subsid = Mylnefield Research Services }} The '''Scottish Crop Research Institute''' more commonly known as the '''SCRI''' was a scientific institute located in [[Invergowrie]] near [[Dundee]], [[Scotland]]. As of April 2011, when SCRI merged with the [[Macaulay Institute|Macaulay Land Use Institute]] it is now part of The [[James Hutton Institute]]. ==History== The institute was opened in 1951 in Invergowrie under the name '''Scottish Horticultural Research Institute''' (SHRI). In 1981, the SHRI merged with the [[Scottish Plant Breeding Station]] (SPBS), which at the time was located near [[Edinburgh]]. Operations of the SPBS moved to the institute's site at Invergowrie and became the Scottish Crop Research Institute.{{cite web |url=http://www.scri.ac.uk/aboutus/history |title=SCRI - History |accessdate=12 April 2009 |last= |first= |year=2009 |work= |publisher=Scottish Crop Research Institute}} In 1987 the institute accepted managerial responsibility for Biomathematics & Statistics Scotland, formerly the Scottish Agricultural Statistics Service.[http://www.bioss.ac.uk/ Biomathematics & Statistics Scotland Homepage] The commercial arm of the SCRI, Mylnefield Research Services, was launched in 1989.[http://www.mrsltd.com/ MRS ltd Homepage] In April 2011 SCRI merged with the [[Macaulay Institute|Macaulay Land Use Institute]] to form a new body, The [[James Hutton Institute]]. The [[chief executive]] of the new institute is Professor Iain Gordon.{{cite web |url=http://www.scri.ac.uk/newinstitute |title=New Institute, SCRI Macaulay merger |accessdate=29 October 2010 |last= |first= |year=2009 |work= |publisher=Scottish Crop Research Institute |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722105727/http://www.scri.ac.uk/newinstitute/ |archivedate=22 July 2012 |df= }} ==Research== The SCRI has both staff and [[PhD]] students who do research into several different aspects of [[plant science]]. Research facilities include [[laboratories]], office space, [[glasshouses]], growth chambers and 172 [[hectares]] of land which is used for field work.{{cite web |url=http://www.scri.ac.uk/aboutus/facilities |title=SCRI Facilities |accessdate=12 April 2009 |last= |first= |year=2009 |work= |publisher=SCRI}} Research at SCRI is organised into four programmes: environment plant interactions, [[plant pathology]], [[genetics]] and plant products and food quality.{{cite web |url=http://www.scri.ac.uk/research |title=Research Programmes at SCRI |accessdate=12 April 2009 |last= |first= |year=2009 |work= |publisher=Scottish Crop Research Institute}} The institute carries out research funded by the [[Scottish Government]]'s "Programme 1" for profitable and sustainable agriculture and the co-ordinator of Programme 1 is staff member Professor Howard Davies.{{cite web |url=http://www.programme1.net/ |title=Programme 1 |accessdate=12 April 2009 |last= |first= |work= |publisher=SCRI and The Scottish Government}} The institute is also undertaking research into how [[climate change]] in Scotland will affect crop production,{{cite web |url=http://www.scri.ac.uk/scri/file/cross%20cutting%20themes/Climate_change.pdf |title=Climate Change Research at the SCRI|accessdate=12 April 2009 |last=Newton |first=AC |author2=Gregory, PJ |year=2007 |work= |publisher=SCRI}} as the institute is involved with the Scottish Government's Agriculture and Climate Change Stakeholder Group.{{cite web |url=http://openscotland.gov.uk/Publications/2008/05/15115150/11 |title=Annex B - Agriculture and Climate Change Stakeholder Group: Membership |accessdate=12 April 2009 |last= |first= |date=May 2008 |work= |publisher=Agriculture and Climate Change Stakeholder Group}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.scri.ac.uk/ Scottish Crop Research Institute] *[http://www.hutton.ac.uk/ The James Hutton Institute] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121108052713/http://groups.google.com/group/nvrs-hri-gg/web/arc-institutes#SHRI Units and Institutes of the Agricultural Research Council] {{coord|56.4565|-3.0694|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} [[Category:Research institutes in Scotland]] [[Category:Agricultural research institutes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Government research]] [[Category:Perth and Kinross]] [[Category:Agriculture in Scotland]] [[Category:1951 establishments in Scotland]]

'''Short food supply chain''' ('''SFSCs''') is a broad range of food production-distribution-consumption configurations, such as [[farmers' markets]], [[farm shop]]s, collective farmers' shops, [[Community supported agriculture|community-supported agriculture]], solidarity purchase groups. More in general, a food [[supply chain]] can be defined as "short" when it is characterized by short distance or few intermediaries between producers and consumers.
== Origin of the concept == SFSCs were originally identified as examples of "resistance" of farmers to modernization of the food system, characterized by the development of supply chains based on long-distance trade.<ref name="Ploeg">Van Der Ploeg, Jan Douwe, Henk Renting, Gianluca Brunori, Karlheinz Knickel, Joe Mannion, Terry Marsden, and others, “Rural Development: From Practices and Policies Towards Theory,” Sociologia Ruralis, 40 (2000), 391–408 <doi:10.1111/1467-9523.00156></ref> Resistance consists in the fact that, by selling directly to consumers, farmers bypass intermediaries and thus can develop autonomous marketing strategies based on differentiation. These strategies give farmers the possibility of keeping a bigger share of the value added within the farm and within the local economies. Given these characteristics, short food supply chains are increasingly taken into consideration by rural and food policies as a driver of change in the food system and a policy tool for [[rural development]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/agriculture/events/small-farmers-conference-2012_en.htm |title=Conference "Local agriculture and short food supply chains" (Brussels, 20/04/2012) - Agriculture and rural development |publisher=Ec.europa.eu |date= |accessdate=2012-10-23}}</ref>
The analysis of short food supply chains has fed a broader debate on "alternative food chains",<ref name="Ilbery">Ilbery, B., and D. Maye. 2005. «Alternative(shorter) food supply chains and specialist livestock products in the Scottish- English borders». Environment and planning A 37 (5): 823–844.</ref> "alternative food networks",<ref>Goodman, D., and M. Goodman. 2008. «Alternative food networks». International encyclopedia of human geography, pp.(Oxford: Elsevier).</ref> and "sustainable food chains".<ref>Roep, D., and H. Wiskerke. 2006. Nourishing networks: fourteen lessons about creating sustainable food supply chains. Reed Business Information, Wageningen University.</ref>
=== Specificity === SFSCs are considered the most appropriate channels for organic and locally specific products and for small farmers. In fact, a closer relation between producers and consumers gives producers the opportunity to develop a richer communication, and to identify market niches. Ilbery and Maye state, “the crucial characteristic of SFSCs is that foods which reach the final consumer have been transmitted through an SC that is 'embedded' with value-laden information concerning the mode of production, provenance, and distinctive quality assets of the product”.<ref name="Ilbery" /><ref name="Renting H. 2003 pages 393 - 411">Renting H., Marsden T. , Banks J. (2003) Understanding alternative food networks: exploring the role of short food supply chains in rural development. Environment and Planning A 2003, volume 35, pages 393 - 411</ref> Likewise, Marsden et al. (2000) state that “a common characteristic, however, is the emphasis upon the type of relationship between the producer and the consumer in these supply chains, and the role of this relationship in constructing value and meaning, rather than solely the type of product itself”.<ref>Marsden, T., J. Banks, e G. Bristow. 2000. «Food supply chain approaches: exploring their role in rural development». Sociologia ruralis 40 (4): 424–438.</ref>
=== Dimensions of proximity === In order to develop a definition of SFSCs, there are a number of candidate criteria that may be used. SFSCs have been conceptualized in terms of Dimensions of Proximity. Kebir and Torre (2012) were perhaps some of the first to propose such a conceptualization, classifying SFSCs based on two dimensions: Geographical Proximity and "Organized" Proximity, the latter of which incorporates social notions of Belonging and Similarity.<ref name="kebir">Kebir, L. and Torre A. (2012) Geographical proximity and new short food supply chains. In: Lazzeretti, Luciana (ed.) 2012. Creative Industries and Innovation in Europe: Concepts, Measures and Comparative Case Studies. Routledge.</ref> Other dimensions have been proposed, including [citations needed]: * '''Geographical proximity''': physically close, and is measured as a distance between producers and consumers * '''Social proximity''': expression is direct (with very few intermediaries) and trustful relations between a producer and consumer who know each other and the product, solidarity between producers and consumers, civic engagement in local food system, (re)connection with local food traditions and identities * '''Economic proximity''': market exchanges happen and money circulates within a community or a certain locality (owned and governed locally, transparent, and traceable) ==Classification== SFSCs are classified by Renting et al.<ref name="Renting H. 2003 pages 393 - 411" /> into face-to-face, proximate, extended. '''Face to face''' are characterized by physical encounters between producers and consumers (as in the case of farmers' markets). In the '''proximate''' short food supply chains producers are not necessarily managing product distribution (as in the case of consumers' cooperatives). In the '''extended''' short food supply chains, although [[geographical distance]]s between producers and consumers may be long, consumers are aware of the identity of the producers and of the products (such as in the case of [[fair trade]] and protected denominations of origin).
== Regulations == An action plan developed in 2009 at the [[Ministry of Agriculture (France)|Ministry of Agriculture, Agrifood, and Forestry]] of France was aimed at supporting the development of short food chains. According to the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130207121841/http://agriculture.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/100809-lettreCircuitsCourts.pdf plan], short food chains are defined on the base of the number of actors involved; precisely : SFSC are considered as « ''commercialisation of agricultural products through direct selling or indirect selling when only one intermediary is involved'' ». (« ''Un circuit court est un mode de commercialisation des produits agricoles qui s'exerce soit par la vente directe du producteur au consommateur, soit par la vente indirecte à condition qu'il n'y ait qu'un seul intermédiaire''. » .
However, there have been discussions at the senate and at regional levels that short-ness should not be reduced to the number of intermediaries but also geographical distance should be considered (f.i., one can buy vine directly, but what if it travels 1,000 km?). Following the national action plan (or maybe prior to it in some cases), regional SFSC plans have been developed. Regional action plans refer to the definition above, but they also complement or precise it. F.i. Aquitaine region also adds short or reduced geographical distance between producers and consumers [https://web.archive.org/web/20120404130325/http://agri-agro.aquitaine.fr/uploads/media/Plan_Regional_Circuits_courts.pdf (link)]. The French Law on modernisation of agriculture and fishing, updated in 2010 (n° 2010-874), among its many other intervention actions also states «''the development of short food chains and facilitation of geographical proximity between producers and processors''. »
==Examples==
[[Farmers' market]]s, are physical retail markets featuring foods sold directly by farmers to consumers.
[[Community-supported agriculture|Community-supported agriculture (CSA)]], network or association of individuals who have pledged to support one or more local farms, with growers and consumers sharing the risks and benefits of food production. The [http://www.urgenci.net URGENCI network] federates initiatives of CSA from all over the world.
[[:it:Gruppo di acquisto solidale|Gruppi di acquisto solidale (GAS)]] Italian networks initiated by consumers that link up to farmers to organize alternative food provision
[http://www.reseau-amap.org/Les AMAP] (''French Associations pour le maintien d'une agriculture paysanne'') support peasant and [[organic agriculture]] through direct links between farmers and consumers
==Research projects== * [http://glamur.eu GLAMUR] - Global and local food assessment: a multidimensional performance-based approach * [http://www.foodlinkscommunity.net FOODLINKS] - Knowledge brokerage to promote sustainable food consumption and production: linking scientists, policymakers, and civil society organisations * [http://www.sus-chain.org/index.htm SUS-CHAINS] - Marketing sustainable agriculture: an analysis of the potential role of new food supply chains in sustainable rural development * [http://purefoodnetwork.eu/ PUREFOOD] - is a Marie Curie Initial Training Network funded by the European Commission’s Seventh Framework PEOPLE program. The objective of PUREFOOD is to train a pool of early-stage researchers in the socio-economic and socio-spatial dynamics of the (peri-)urban and regional foodscape
==See also== * [[Food_systems#Alternative_food_systems|Alternative food systems]] * [http://enrd.ec.europa.eu/app_templates/filedownload.cfm?id=E8F24E08-0A45-F272-33FB-A6309E3AD601 Local food and short food supply chains], an ENRD (European Network of Rural Development) publication * [http://ftp.jrc.es/EURdoc/JRC80420.pdf Short Food Supply Chains and Local Food Systems in the EU. A State of Play of their Socio-Economic Characteristics.] a publication of the Joint Research Centre of the European Commission * [http://www.foodlinkscommunity.net/fileadmin/documents_organicresearch/foodlinks/CoPs/evidence-document-sfsc-cop.pdf Short Food Supply Chains as drivers of sustainable development. Evidence Document]. This document is the result of a joint collaboration among practitioners, policy makers and scientists who joined in the Short Food Supply Chains Community of Practice, established within the Foodlinks project (in the framework of the FP7 project FOODLINKS GA No. 265287)

The '''South Tyrolean Liberation Committee''' ({{lang-de|Befreiungsausschuss Südtirol}}, abbreviated ''BAS'') was an underground secessionist organisation founded by [[Sepp Kerschbaumer]] and several combatants in the mid-1950s which aimed to achieve the right for [[self-determination]] for [[South Tyrol]] and the related [[secession]] from [[Italy]] via bomb attacks.<ref>{{cite book | last = Fasser | first = Manuel | title = Ein Tirol – zwei Welten. Das politische Erbe der Südtiroler Feuernacht von 1961 | publisher = Studienverlag | location=Innsbruck | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-3-7065-4783-3 | page=37 }}</ref>
The organisation's history can be divided into two stages.<ref name="Steininger2003">Rolf Steininger (2003). ''South Tyrol: A Minority Conflict of the Twentieth Century.'' New Brunswick, New Jersey: Transaction Publishers. {{ISBN|978-0-7658-0800-4}}</ref> In the first phase, from 1956 until 1961, the activists focussed on symbolic targets such as relics of the [[Italian Fascism|fascist regime]], trying to avoid physical injuries of human beings. On 12 June 1961, the BAS organized the bombing of 37 electricity pylons supplying power to the industrial zone of [[Bolzano]], later known as the [[Night of Fire]] (''Feuernacht''). After the subsequent imprisonment of almost all leading members, a second, more violent phase began. This second phase was characterised by an increasing infiltration of Austrian and German [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazis]] and intensified [[secret service]] activities which culminated in several assassinations and ambushes on Italian security forces.<ref>{{Citation | last = Steurer| first = Leopold| author-link = | contribution = Propaganda im „Befreiungskampf“ | editor-last = Obermair| editor-first = Hannes| title = Regionale Zivilgesellschaft in Bewegung – Cittadini innanzi tutto | isbn = 978-3-85256-618-4 | pages = 386–400 | publisher = Folio Verlag | place = Vienna–Bozen| year = 2013 }}</ref> With the progression of negotiations concerning South Tyrolean autonomy in the late 1960s, the BAS became less active.<ref>{{cite book | last = Steininger | first = Rolf | title = Südtirol – Vom Ersten Weltkrieg bis zur Gegenwart | publisher = Studienverlag | location=Innsbruck | year = 2003 | isbn = 3-7065-1348-X | pages=82–86 }}</ref>

[[File:Vila Milada (02).jpg|thumb|Milada after eviction in 2009]]
'''Squat Milada''' was one of the Czech Republic's best known squats, located in the [[Libeň]] district of [[Prague]].<ref>{{cite web | url =http://praha.idnes.cz/soud-zasah-policie-v-squatu-milada-d53-/praha-zpravy.aspx?c=A150525_173341_praha-zpravy_klu | title =Soudy musí znovu řešit přiměřenost policejního zásahu ve squatu Milada | last = | first = | date =2015 | website =Idnes | publisher = | access-date =2015-11-06 | quote = }} </ref> Milada was intended to be demolished in the 1980s and thus deleted from the Land Registry, becoming a house which officially did not exist. The squat was occupied in 1997, evicted in 2009, then reoccupied for a day in 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://domaci.ihned.cz/c1-37637730-posledni-prazsky-squat-vila-milada-ma-namale-vyklizi-ji-bezpecnostni-agentura | title =Poslední pražský squat, vila Milada, má namále. Vyklízí ji bezpečnostní agentura | last = | first = | date =2009 | website =Hospodářské Noviny | publisher =Ihned | access-date =2015-11-06 | quote = }}</ref> Whilst it acted as a [[social centre]] and [[infoshop]] hosting concerts and events, Milada was also home to a number of people.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://prazsky.denik.cz/zpravy_region/psiplenili20080227.html | title =Aktualizováno: Psi, kteří plenili v pražské zoo, utekli při venčení | last = | first = | date =2008 | website = | publisher = | access-date =2015-11-06 | quote = }}</ref>
==Occupation== Left derelict in 1988, Milada was occupied in 1997, along with the neighbouring villa, Miluška.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://domaci.ihned.cz/c1-37637730-posledni-prazsky-squat-vila-milada-ma-namale-vyklizi-ji-bezpecnostni-agentura | title =Poslední pražský squat, vila Milada, má namále. Vyklízí ji bezpečnostní agentura | last = | first = | date =2009 | website =Hospodářské Noviny | publisher =Ihned | access-date =2015-11-06 | quote = }}</ref> The villa was used as an infoshop, a bicycle repair workshop, a cafe, a meeting space and a venue for punk gigs and experimental music. In October 1988, the police attempted to evict the building but were repelled, with squatters remaining on the roof for several days.
==Eviction== The eviction in 2009 became a large media story.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.radio.cz/en/section/curraffrs/eviction-of-milada-squat-becomes-political-cause-celebre | title =Eviction of Milada squat becomes political cause célèbre | last =Cameron | first =Rob | date =2009 | website =RadioPrague | publisher = | access-date =2015-11-06 | quote = }}</ref> The house was then briefly reoccupied a week later amid fears that it would be demolished.<ref>{{cite web | url =https://en.squat.net/2009/07/07/prague-no-to-demolition-of-milada/ | title =Prague: No to demolition of Milada | last = | first = | date =2009 | website =squat!net | publisher = | access-date =2015-11-06 | quote = }}</ref>
==After eviction== A party in Milada to commemorate three years since the eviction was broken up by the police on June 30, 2012. A helicopter and 100 police arrested 25 people for various offences.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/police-crackdown-on-squatters-in-the-milada-mansion | title =Police crackdown on squatters in the Milada mansion | last =Falvey | first =Christian | date =2012 | website =RadioPrague | publisher = | access-date =2015-11-06 | quote = }}</ref>
In 2015, there was a debate in the media as the Supreme Administrative Court considered an appeal regarding the legality of the eviction of Milada.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://praha.idnes.cz/soud-zasah-policie-v-squatu-milada-d53-/praha-zpravy.aspx?c=A150525_173341_praha-zpravy_klu | title =Soudy musí znovu řešit přiměřenost policejního zásahu ve squatu Milada | last = | first = | date =2015 | website =Idnes | publisher = | access-date =2015-11-06 | quote = }} </ref>
