'''WE ACT for Environmental Justice''' (formerly known as '''West Harlem Environmental Action''') is a [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] [[environmental justice]] organization based in [[Harlem, New York City]]. The organization was founded in March 1988 to mobilize community opposition to the city's operation of the North River Sewage Treatment Plant, and the siting of the sixth bus depot in Northern Manhattan. [[File:Harlem NYC.JPG|thumb|Bird's Eye view of Harlem, New York City]]
WE ACT is dedicated to fighting environmental justice issues in the Northern Manhattan community.The organization focuses on urban quality of life issues such as [[climate justice]], clean air, access to good jobs, [[public health]], [[pollution]], and sustainable and equitable land use. It works through citizen empowerment, lobbying, litigation, education, and community outreach to accomplish its goals.
Currently, WE ACT is one of several groups engaged in negotiations for a [[Community Benefits Agreement]] with [[Columbia University]] as part of the school's [[Manhattanville, Manhattan|Manhattanville]] expansion plan. It is also renovating an abandoned [[brownstone]] for conversion into the WE ACT Environmental Justice Center, which will house office and program space as well as serve as a demonstration of various [[Environmental technology|green building technologies]].
== History and organization == In April 1986, the North River Sewage Treatment Plant began its operations on eight blocks of riverside property in [[Harlem|West Harlem, New York]].<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title=Noxious New York: The Racial Politics of Urban Health and Environmental Justice|last=Sze|first=Julie|publisher=MIT Press|year=2006|isbn=|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|pages=}}</ref> Soon after its opening, local residents from the predominantly African American and Latino neighborhood complained of noxious odors emitting from the plant and increased exposures to health hazards.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Shepard|first=Peggy|date=July–August 2007|title=BUILDING COMMUNITY POWER FOR CHANGE|url=|journal=The Crisis|volume=114|pages=}}</ref> [[Peggy Shepard]], a local resident, who was elected as a political district leader in 1985, pressured local and state authorities to perform a study on the health effects of exposure to the treatment plant's emissions.<ref name=":11" /> The study found that the fumes may cause respiratory problems at high levels of exposure, triggering public backlash from West Harlem residents, demanding repairs be made on the facility.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Thigpen|first=David|last2=Kuznik|first2=Frank|date=October 1993|title=People who make a difference|url=|journal=National Wildlife|volume=31|issue=6|pages=44–51}}</ref>
In 1988 the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) attempted to construct a second bus depot in West Harlem, adjacent to an intermediary school. The MTA was met with strong community opposition, in the form of protests, lawsuits, and scientific research.<ref name=":13" />
During this period, the attention and discontent surrounding the operation of the North River Sewage Treatment Plant and the construction of a second bus depot in West Harlem, presented the need for a unified movement to address the unequal impact of environmental hazards on the minority community. Therefore, in March 1988 Peggy Shepard, Vernice Miller-Travis, and Chuck Sutton launched WE ACT to "institutionalize resources in the community" to build and educate a community dedicated to fighting environmental injustice and improving environmental health.<ref name=":13" />
WE ACT emphasizes the importance of citizen involvement in its campaigns and partnerships.It utilizes community-based participatory research to address environmental justice issues and improve the environmental health and quality of life of the Northern Manhattan community.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Shepard |first=PM|date=2017-05-06|title=Advancing Environmental Justice through Community-Based Participatory Research|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|volume=110|issue=Suppl 2|pages=139|issn=0091-6765|pmc=1241155|doi=10.1289/ehp.02110s2139}}</ref> WE ACT strives to educate community members and raise public awareness on issues effecting the health and quality of life of the community.
== Early work ==
=== North River Sewage Treatment Plant === The construction of the North River Sewage Treatment Plant, was initially proposed for a site along the [[Hudson River]] at 72nd Street, a primarily white and affluent community; however, the site was rejected due to community opposition and logistical problems.<ref name=":14">{{Cite web |url=http://www.umich.edu/~snre492/ny.html|title=New York Justice Page|website=www.umich.edu|access-date=2017-03-29}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} Thus, the site relocated to 137th Street in West Harlem, a predominantly Latino and African-American neighborhood. Local residents were outraged by the new sitting of the sewage plant in their community, concerned it would worsen preexisting pollution problems.<ref name=":7" /> Despite community resistance, construction of the plant started in 1972 and was completed in 1985. When the plant began its operations in 1986, community members further voiced their concerns over noxious odors emanating from the plant effecting an area of almost two miles. Local residents remained indoors to escape the fumes, partly due to their fear of developing adverse health effects resulting from exposure to the fumes.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/opinion/the-editorial-notebook-the-foul-mystery-of-north-river.html|title=The Editorial Notebook; The Foul Mystery of North River|last=Purnick|first=Joyce|authorlink=Joyce Purnick|date=1989-12-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-05-05|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> A study by the New York Department of Energy Conservation (DEC), found the plant's emissions contained hydrogen sulfide levels 28% higher than the standard.<ref name=":7" /> Community discontent shifted into activism and in 1988 on [[Martin Luther King Jr. Day|Martin Luther King Day]], WE ACT co-founders Peggy Shepard and Chuck Sutton, along with several others were arrested for blocking traffic around the treatment facility, as an act of protest against the poor operation and management of the plant.<ref name=":7" />
Due to lawsuits filed by community organizations, resistance from West Harlem residents, and pressure from WE ACT, city officials addressed the plant's operating issues in 1991 and located a design flaw that was causing the excess air pollution.<ref name=":14" /> After a prolonged court battle with the city and the [[New York City Department of Environmental Protection|Department of Environmental Protection]] (DEP), WE ACT came to a settlement regarding the operations of the sewage plant in December 1993.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Shepard|first=Peggy|date=2005-01-01|title=Breathe At Your Own Risk: Transit Justice in West Harlem|jstor=41555237|journal=Race, Poverty & the Environment|volume=12|issue=1|pages=51–53}}</ref> As a result, $1.1 million was set aside in a fund for communal environmental initiatives in West Harlem and WE ACT was made "a monitor of the city's $55 million consent agreement to fix the plant".<ref name=":8" />
In an act of appeasement to the West Harlem community for the faulty operating of the sewage plant and occupation of limited open space, the state constructed a 28-acre state park known as the [[Riverbank State Park]] on top of the sewage plant in 1993.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/17/nyregion/atop-a-harlem-waste-plant-a-park-grows.html|title=Atop a Harlem Waste Plant, a Park Grows|last=Dunlap |first=David W.|date=1989-05-17|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-05-06|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> However, fumes and odors continued to seep out of the plant affecting local neighborhoods.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://ejatlas.org/conflict/north-river-sewage-treatment-plant|title=North River Sewage Treatment Plant, USA {{!}} EJAtlas|last=EJOLT|website=Environmental Justice Atlas|language=en|access-date=2017-03-29}}</ref>
Today the North River Sewage Treatment Plant is continuing to improve their facility and upgrade to meet higher air quality standards. In their most recent endeavors the facility has installed new duct work and fans to optimize odor control and reported air issues.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/dep/html/dep_projects/cp_north_river_plant.shtml|title=North River Wastewater Treatment Plant|website=www.nyc.gov|access-date=2017-05-01}}</ref>
=== Dirty Diesel === Northern Manhattan is home to one-third of "the largest diesel bus fleet (4,000 vehicles) in the country" operated by the New York [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] (MTA).<ref name=":8" /> WE ACT deemed the high concentration of bus depots had negative impacts on air quality and the subsequent health of Northern Manhattan community members.The organization associated the high rates of asthma in Northern Manhattan with concentrated levels of [[Particulates|particulate matter]] (PM), an air pollutant released during diesel fuel combustion, emanating from the bus depots, major transportation routes, and heavy traffic throughout West Harlem.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Northridge|first=M. E.|last2=Yankura|first2=J.|last3=Kinney|first3=P. L.|last4=Santella|first4=R. M.|last5=Shepard|first5=P.|last6=Riojas|first6=Y.|last7=Aggarwal|first7=M.|last8=Strickland|first8=P.|date=1999-07-01|title=Diesel exhaust exposure among adolescents in Harlem: a community-driven study|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=89|issue=7|pages=998–1002|issn=0090-0036|pmc=1508854|pmid=10394306|doi=10.2105/ajph.89.7.998}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> WE ACT also organized a media campaign, ''The Clean Fuel--Clean Air--Good Health Diesel Bus Campaign'', to raise public awareness on the risks associated with diesel exhaust and its ability to trigger asthma attacks.<ref name=":8" /> While it failed to influence New York's MTA to change its policies in favor of cleaner fuel alternatives, the campaign garnered a large amount of public support and attention,<ref name=":0" /> demonstrating the power of public media and community outreach.
In November 2000, WE ACT, filed a complaint with the [[United States Department of Transportation|U.S. Department of Transportation]] claiming that bus depots were disproportionately located in minority communities in Northern Manhattan, which houses six of the eight total bus depots in Manhattan, thus elevating the health risks associated with high exposure to harmful diesel exhaust.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://ejatlas.org/print/west-harlem-and-the-metropolitan-transportation-authority-usa|title=Environmental Justice Atlas|last=EJOLT|website=ejatlas.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-29}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
The Department of Transportation found that the MTA violated Title IV of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] and failed to meet the federal environmental impact analysis involving the construction, rehabilitation, and operation of bus depots and other facilities. This campaign led to the MTA's modification of bus depots and investment in clean-fuel buses, as well as increased public awareness pertaining to the dangers of fuel fumes and poor air quality.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.weact.org/Portals/7/NYTEnvironGroupFilesComplaintAgainstMTA.pdf|title=Environmental Group Files Complaint Against M.T.A.|last=Cardwell|first=Diane|date=16 November 2000|work=New York Times|access-date=28 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Mission == WE ACT states its mission is "to build healthy communities by ensuring that people of color and/or low income residents participate meaningfully in the creation of sound and fair environmental health and protection policies and practices."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.weact.org/whoweare/ourstory/ |title=Our Story|last=|first=|date=|website=WE ACT|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 27, 2017}}</ref> The organization serves as an "educational resource" to galvanize citizen participation and activism on matters of "environmental health and quality of life issues".<ref name=":8" />
== Environmental justice ==
=== Asthma === In the United States the number of people suffering from [[Asthma]] has grown steadily every year.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/vitalsigns/asthma/ |title=Asthma in the US|last=|first=|date=May 2011|website=Center for Disease Control and Prevention|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5/4/17}}</ref> Healthcare professionals have referred to the alarming rise in asthma cases as "a new epidemic".<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=Phil|last2=Mayer|first2=Brian|last3=Zavestoski|first3=Stephen |last4=Luebke|first4=Theo |last5=Mandelbaum |first5=Joshua|last6=McCormick|first6=Sabrina|date=2003|title=The health politics of asthma: environmental justice and collective illness experience in the United States|url=|journal=Social Science & Medicine|volume=57|issue=3|pages=453–464 |doi=10.1016/s0277-9536(02)00375-1}}</ref> The [[respiratory disease]] is characterized by [[Chronic inflammation|chronic]] lung inflammation and episodes of airway constriction.<ref name=":10" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Boehlke |first=Paul |last2=Huang |first2=Shih-Wen|last3=Small|first3=Caroline|date=January 2017|title=Asthma|url=|journal=Magill’s Medical Guide (Online Edition). |volume= |pages=}}</ref> While there is uncertainty on the exact cause of the disease, it is believed that "genetic and environmental factors interact to cause asthma, most often early in life".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/asthma/causes|title=What causes asthma?|last=|first=|date=|website=NIH National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5/4/17}}</ref> Recently, the focus has turned to the impact of environmental conditions, most notably the exposure to indoor and outdoor air pollutants or allergens.<ref name=":0" /> WE ACT states that a racial divide exists in air pollution, resulting in the disproportionate exposure of minority or low income communities to high levels of air pollutants.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.weact.org/whatwedo/areasofwork/cleanair/|title=Clean Air {{!}} WE ACT for Environmental Justice|work=WE ACT for Environmental Justice|access-date=2017-05-05|language=en-US}}</ref> WE ACT works to improve the air quality of Northern Manhattan communities and reduce the incidence of asthma and other respiratory problems by addressing the sources and environmental risks producing harmful [[Air pollution|air pollutants]].<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":0" />
WE ACT focuses on asthma or [[clean air]] as one of its primary areas of concern, because of exceptionally high rates of asthma found in Northern Manhattan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/about/press/pr2016/pr088-16.page|title=Health Department Launches Asthma Campaign "Your Child’s Asthma Is Always There, Even When They Seem Perfectly Fine"|last=|first=|date=November 3, 2016|website=NYC Health|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5/4/17}}</ref> The organization highlights the connection between environmental risks in the predominantly Latino and African-American neighborhoods, such as the disproportionate exposure to diesel exhaust and the ubiquitous odors from municipal facilities, and the highest asthma mortality and morbidity rates in New York.<ref name=":8" /> WE ACT the challenges the city and state to recognize and address air quality problems.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://rootsofhealthinequity.org/|title=A Neighborhood Fights Back|last=|first=|date=April 24, 2017|website=National Association of County & City Health Officials|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Currently WE ACT, is collaborating with several [[Community-Based Organization|community-based]] environmental organizations, such as the Deep South Center for Environmental Justice (DSCEJ), Green Door Initiative (GDI), and Jesus People Against Pollution (JPAP), on the ''National Asthma Disparities Project''.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=https://www.weact.org/campaigns/national-asthma-disparities-project/|title=National Asthma Disparities Project - WE ACT for Environmental Justice|work=WE ACT for Environmental Justice|access-date=2017-05-05|language=en-US}}</ref> The project aims to study the disparities in asthma treatment across four different communities in the United States, by assessing the effectiveness of the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]]'s (EPA) ''Coordinated Federal Action Plan to Reduce Racial and Ethnic Asthma Disparities (Action Plan)''.<ref name=":9" /> ''The Action Plan'' was introduced in May 2012, to review federal efforts addressing asthma issues and develop a more effective collaboration among federal programs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ashley|first=Peter|last2=Freemer|first2=Michelle|last3=Garbe|first3=Paul|last4=Rowson|first4=David|date=March–April 2017|title=Coordinated Federal Actions Are Needed to Reduce Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Childhood Asthma|url=http://journals.lww.com/jphmp/Fulltext/2017/03000/Coordinated_Federal_Actions_Are_Needed_to_Reduce.21.aspx|journal=Journal of Public Health Management & Practice|volume=23|pages=207–209|doi=10.1097/phh.0000000000000541}}</ref>
== Partnerships ==
=== Community Outreach and Engagement Core (COEC) === The Community Outreach and Engagement Core (COEC) is a collaborative program between the [[National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences|NIEHS]] Center for Environmental Health in Northern Manhattan, WE ACT, and other community stakeholders, working to understand and prevent the environmental aspects of diseases such as Parkinson's, Cancer, Asthma, and ALS through policy and legislation.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://ccceh.org/our-research/community-outreach-and-research-translation/community-outreach|title=Community Outreach and Engagement - CCCEH.org|work=CCCEH.org|access-date=2017-05-05|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":18">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mailman.columbia.edu/programs/niehs-center-environmental-health-northern-manhattan/community-outreach|title=Community Engagement Core {{!}} Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health|website=www.mailman.columbia.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-05-05}}</ref> The operations of the COEC focus on four Northern Manhattan communities: Central Harlem, West Harlem, Washington Heights, and Inwood.<ref name=":18" /> Other members of the program include organizations within a close proximity to Northern Manhattan, such as The Columbia Center for Children's Environmental Health (CCCEH) of Columbia University, The Harlem Center for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention, and the Harlem Hospital Center.<ref name=":18" /> One of the biggest accomplishments of COEC and WE ACT is the development of an Environmental Health Report Card.<ref name=":18" /> The report card assigns a grade to New York City communities based on measurements of indoor/outdoor air quality, recreational water quality, solid waste, open space, and the availability of healthy food. By communicating scientific and health research findings through initiatives such as family events and fairs, conferences, forums, and the Environmental Health Report Card, the COEC members seek to increase community awareness of environmental dangers and establish a consistent local involvement in environmental issues.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":5" />
WE ACT's involvement in Northern Manhattan communities allows COEC members to acquire information about local environmental health concerns. In turn, WE ACT acts as a bridge for the passing of information between research groups and low-income communities in Northern Manhattan.<ref name=":9" />
=== Faith Leaders for Environmental Justice === WE ACT has collaborated with members of diverse Northern Manhattan churches in an effort to raise public awareness of environmental issues.<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=http://www.weact.nyc/Coalitions/FaithLeadersforEnvironmentalJustice/tabid/360/Default.aspx|title=faith leaders for environmental justice|last=WEACT.org|website=www.weact.nyc|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-05}}</ref> The goal of the partnership is to encourage people of faith to care about environmental issues and to educate religious figures so that they can inspire environmental justice activism throughout diverse communities that, traditionally, have not engaged in environmental justice issues.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web |url=http://www.innerself.com/content/social/democracy/activism/8646-working-with-faith-leaders-for-environmental-justice.html|title=Working With Faith Leaders For Environmental Justice|last=Shepard|first=Peggy M.|website=www.innerself.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-05-05}}</ref> [[Faith Leaders for Environmental Justice]] focuses on three key points: Climate Justice, Food Justice, and Energy Consumption. The Climate Justice work group seeks to promote awareness surrounding the dangers of climate change and the behavioral alterations that can be made to mitigate the effects. In coordination with the Energy Consumption work group, one of the main points of the Climate Justice group is to teach people how to reduce their energy consumption and carbon emissions.<ref name=":12" /> The Food Justice work group aims to educate people about the barriers to healthy eating and the importance of purchasing healthy food, while bringing healthful food initiatives to low-income communities.<ref name=":12" /> Some of these initiatives include Community Sponsored Agriculture (CSA) projects, community and rooftop gardens, food drives, and food stamp outreach.<ref name=":17" />
=== Healthy Home Healthy Child Campaign === The Healthy Homes Project is a joint research initiative between the Columbia University Center for Children's Environmental Health (CCCEH). The project targets the unequal exposure of environmental hazards faced by children in minority or low-income communities and works to educate families on a number of known risk factors such as "cigarettes, lead poisoning, drugs and alcohol, air pollution, garbage, pesticides, and poor nutrition".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Toxic Exposures: Contested Illnesses and the Environmental Health Movement|last=Brown|first=Phil|publisher=Columbia University Press|year=2007 |isbn=|location=|pages=123}}</ref> Educating parents on environmental health risks, can protect children from developing asthma or cancer or from experiencing growth or developmental delays, among others.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=O'Fallon|first=Liam|last2=Dearry|first2=Allen|date=April 2002 |title=Community-based participatory research as a tool to advance environmental health sciences|url=|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|volume=110|pages=|doi=10.1289/ehp.02110s2155}}</ref>
